content.title: Noob Orientation: What You’re Looking At
content.content:
**What you’re looking at**
You’ll usually see circuit types as labels on a **consumer unit / distribution board** (e.g., L1, RF1) or on drawings (e.g., “Lighting”, “Power”, “Data”).

**What the goal is**
You should be able to:
- Name the **circuit type** (what it’s for)
- Say the **basic principle** (how it behaves / why it’s used)
- Tell **ring vs radial** (loop vs line)

**3 rules you’ll use (repeat these every time)**
1) **Identify the load** (what is it powering?)
2) **Check the arrangement** (does it return to the device = ring, or end at the last point = radial?)
3) **Confirm using the legend / schedule of circuitry** (don’t guess)

**What you’ll practise (I Do → We Do → You Do)**
- I Do: classify circuits in a simple house list
- We Do: classify circuits in a small shop list using the same steps
- You Do: quick questions + one scenario that uses drawing labels + legend

content.title: The Main Circuit Types and Principles
content.content:
**What this is**
In any electrical installation, circuits are categorized by their **function** and sometimes by their **arrangement**. These categories (“circuit types”) help you quickly understand what a circuit is intended to supply and how it is routed from the protective device to the load(s).

**Why it matters**
Electricians must recognize circuit types so they can:
- Apply the correct safety approach and safe isolation planning
- Choose suitable materials and protective devices (later in the unit)
- Use the correct inspection/testing approach (rings vs radials are different)

**Key rules / facts (simple)**
- **Lighting circuits:** supply fixed lighting points. Usually multiple light points, controlled by one or more switches.
- **Power circuits (socket circuits):** supply socket outlets for portable equipment. Often arranged as either **Ring Final** or **Radial**.
- **Heating circuits:** supply fixed, higher-power loads (e.g., shower, immersion, fixed heaters). Often **dedicated** (one appliance on its own circuit) because current can be high for long periods.
- **Alarm & emergency systems:** supply safety-related equipment (e.g., fire alarm, emergency lighting). These are often kept separate from general power/lighting to **reduce the chance** that a fault on general circuits affects safety equipment (exact design varies).
- **Data communications:** carry low-voltage signals (internet/phone/control data), not mains power. Kept away from power cables where practical to reduce interference.
- **Control circuits:** send “commands” (e.g., thermostat signal, contactor coil control). Often lower voltage than the power circuit it controls.

**Ring vs Radial (the physical difference)**
- **Ring final:** leaves the protective device and **returns to the same device** (a loop).
- **Radial:** leaves the protective device and **ends at the last outlet** (a line).

**How to classify a circuit (repeatable method)**
1) **Identify the load**: what is it supplying?
2) **Check the arrangement**: ring (out-and-back) or radial (out-and-stop) when it’s a socket/power circuit.
3) **Confirm using documentation**: check the **legend** and/or **schedule of circuitry** on the drawing, or the circuit schedule/labels on the distribution board.

**Common mistakes**
- Confusing **circuit type** (what it does) with **wiring system** (how it’s installed, e.g., conduit/trunking).
- Assuming all socket circuits are rings (many are radials).
- Thinking data circuits carry 230V (they carry signals).

**Quick recap**
- Circuit types = grouped by purpose (lighting, power, heating, etc.).
- Rings loop back; radials end at the last point.
- Confirm labels using the legend/schedule—don’t guess.

content.title: Common Traps (Read This Before Practice)
content.content:
- **Trap 1: “Power circuit” automatically means ring.** Nope. Power circuits can be ring final or radial.
- **Trap 2: Mixing up purpose vs containment.** “Lighting circuit” is purpose; “conduit” is containment (wiring system).
- **Trap 3: Guessing labels.** Labels vary. Always confirm using the **legend** or **schedule of circuitry**.
- **Trap 4: Data = mains power.** Data circuits are signals. They’re not there to run kettles.

If you follow the 3-rule method (load → arrangement → confirm), you avoid nearly all beginner mistakes.

expectedAnswer: A category based on what a circuit is for and how it is arranged
A category based on purpose and arrangement
How a circuit is used and routed

expectedAnswer: A ring returns to the protective device while a radial ends at the last point

content.title: Worked Example (I Do): Identifying Circuits in a House
content.given: A standard house contains: Upstairs lights, Kitchen sockets (loop), Electric shower, and Smoke alarms.

steps.description: Identify the load category for each item.
steps.result: Upstairs lights = Lighting; Kitchen sockets = Power; Electric shower = Heating; Smoke alarms = Alarm/Safety.

steps.description: Match each load to the correct circuit type (based on purpose).
steps.result: Upstairs lights → Lighting circuit; Kitchen sockets → Power (socket) circuit; Shower → Heating (dedicated) circuit; Smoke alarms → Alarm/Safety circuit.

steps.description: Check the arrangement for the socket/power circuit: ring or radial?
steps.result: Kitchen sockets are described as a loop, so it’s a Ring Final circuit (out and back to the same protective device).

steps.description: State what reference you would use to confirm labels on a drawing or board schedule.
steps.result: Confirm using the drawing legend and/or schedule of circuitry (or the circuit schedule on the distribution board).

content.notes: Use the same method every time: load → arrangement (if sockets) → confirm with legend/schedule.
